content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure shows a 5 row table with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “f of x.” The heading for row 3 is “f prime of x.” The heading for row 4 is “g of x.” The heading for row 5 is “g prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. x is 0; f of x is 10; f prime of x is three halves; g of x is 1; g prime of x is 5. Column 2. x is 2; f of x is 7; f prime of x is negative 8; g of x is 2; g prime of x is 4. Column 3. x is 4; f of x is 4; f prime of x is 3; g of x is negative 3; g prime of x is 2. Column 4. x is 7; f of x is 5; f prime of x is 6; g of x is 0; g prime of x is 8." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid" equalcolumns="true" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mi>g</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

The functions <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> and <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math> are twice differentiable. The table shown gives values of the functions and their first derivatives at selected values of <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>.

(a) Let <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x equals, f of, open parenthesis, g of x, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. Find <math alttext="h prime of 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi><mo>′</mo><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>7</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure shows a 5 row table with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “f of x.” The heading for row 3 is “f prime of x.” The heading for row 4 is “g of x.” The heading for row 5 is “g prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. x is 0; f of x is 10; f prime of x is three halves; g of x is 1; g prime of x is 5. Column 2. x is 2; f of x is 7; f prime of x is negative 8; g of x is 2; g prime of x is 4. Column 3. x is 4; f of x is 4; f prime of x is 3; g of x is negative 3; g prime of x is 2. Column 4. x is 7; f of x is 5; f prime of x is 6; g of x is 0; g prime of x is 8." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid" equalcolumns="true" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mi>g</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

The functions <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> and <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math> are twice differentiable. The table shown gives values of the functions and their first derivatives at selected values of <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>.

(a) Let <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x equals, f of, open parenthesis, g of x, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. Find <math alttext="h prime of 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi><mo>′</mo><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>7</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

(b) Let <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> be a differentiable function such that <math alttext="k prime of x equals, open parenthesis, f of x, close parenthesis, squared, times g of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>k</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mpadded><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mpadded><mo>·</mo><mi>g</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. Is the graph of <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> concave up or concave down at the point where <math alttext="x equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> ?  Give a reason for your answer.

(c) Let <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="m of x equals, 5 times x cubed plus, the integral from 0 to x, of, f prime of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>m</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi>x</mi></msubsup><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="m of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

(d) Is the function <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> defined in part (c) increasing, decreasing, or neither at <math alttext="x equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> ?  Justify your answer.

unit.text: 3: Differentiation: Composite, Implicit, and Inverse Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
